p:
Human activities such as fossil fuel combustion and land use change are the dominant drivers of the fast increase in atmospheric CO 2 concentration
1, 2 . The increase in atmospheric CO 2 concentration has been altering the climate system through additional radiative forcing
1 . Carbon-climate feedback is a major mechanism for regulating climate change. For example, terrestrial ecosystems can uptake about 1/3 fossil-fuel CO 2 emissions
3 and thus have the potential to slow down climate warming. Soils contain the largest carbon (C) stock in terrestrial ecosystems, twice as large as the content of the atmospheric C pool
4 . Therefore, a slight loss in the soil C stock to climate change may cause substantially positive feedback to the atmospheric CO 2, which could further warm the climate system. It is therefore essential to determine the sign and strength of such soil C-climate feedback.
